author: sirber
body:
# Steps to reproduce

```powershell
New-WebApplication -Name "Scms" -PhysicalPath "C:\inetpub\wwwroot\Scms" -Site "Scms" -Force
```

# Expected behavior (as on v5)
```none
Name             Application pool   Protocols    Physical Path
----             ----------------   ---------    -------------
Scms             DefaultAppPool     http         C:\inetpub\wwwroot\Scms
```

# Actual behavior
```none
Name             Application pool   Protocols    Physical Path
----             ----------------   ---------    -------------
                 DefaultAppPool     http         C:\inetpub\wwwroot\Scms
```

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->
```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19569
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: sirber
comments.body:
Cannot test in v6.2.4:

```
Import-Module WebAdministration
Import-Module : Module 'C:\WINDOWS\system32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\Modules\WebAdministration\WebAdministration.psd1' does not support current PowerShell edition 'Core'. Its supported editions are 'Desktop'. Use 'Import-Module -SkipEditionCheck' to ignore the compatibility of this module.
At line:1 char:1
+ Import-Module WebAdministration
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : ResourceUnavailable: (C:\WINDOWS\system32\u2026Administration.psd1:String) [Import-Module], InvalidOperationException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : Modules_PSEditionNotSupported,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.ImportModuleCommand
```

comments.author: sirber
comments.body:
In IIS, the Applications are named correctly.
Get-WebApplication returns empty names too.

comments.author: vexx32
comments.body:
@sirber if the module is not Core-compatible then there's very much not a whole lot we can do in PowerShell.

Your best bet is to import with the `-UseWindowsCompatibility` switch and see if it works well enough with that. Beyond that, the module itself would need to be updated, and those cmdlets aren't owned by the PowerShell team. You'll need to report the issue on UserVoice and have the IIS team get it fixed if that is the case. 🙂

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
All non-compatible module can be reported in https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShellModuleCoverage
GitHub
PowerShell/PowerShellModuleCoverage
Track issues related to using Windows PowerShell modules with PowerShell - PowerShell/PowerShellModuleCoverage

title: New-WebApplication, missing Name
